WORLD BANK Staff Working Paper No. 494 October 1981 -PATTERNS OF BARRIERS TO TRADE IN SWEDEN: A STUDY IN THE THEORY OF PROTECTION This work in progress report is part of an inquiry being undertaken by the World Bank in conjunction with scholars from twelve industrial countries into the penetration of the markets of industrial countries by exports of manufactures from developing countries. The project seeks to establish the shares of industrial country markets held by the developing countries, changes in such shares in the 1970s, and why they vary among industry groups and countries. The aim is to assist developing and industrial countries to improve their policies through a better understanding of trade patterns and protectionist pressures. This paper studies the determinants of the inter-industry pattern of tariffs, non-tariff barriers to trade and domestic subsidies in Sweden, in the light of different hypotheses about causes of protection. The statistical results show that Swedish nominal and effective tariffs protect labor intensive industries in which protection is concentrated in large plants, that are not intensive in the use of skilled labor and research and development (R&D). The results are consistent with the hypothesis that the general goal of trade policy is to diversify the industrial structure by compensating for high comparative costs. Quantitative restrictions on imports follow much the same pattern, but subsidized industries are less homogenous. The author is grateful for valuable comments from the participants in the workshop on protection in developed countries held in Brussels in November 1980.  1. INTRODUCTION The trend towards increasing protectionism in most industrial countries has stimulated interest in the analysis of protection. To be able to influence policy it is important to understand the factors and mechanisms behind protection. This paper is a study of the structure and development of protection in Sweden. Protection is taken not only to mean import restrictions, but also various subsidies to internationally competing industries. Because of -the scarcity of data the analysis is, however, focused on import restrictions, and the econometric analysis treats only tariffs. One objective of the study is to analyze why some industries, but not others, have been granted protection. The explanation is sought in terms of differences in general characteristics of the production process, of the market and of the industrial structure. Section 2 gives a short survey of some of the theories that explain protection, while the econometric analysis is presented in Section 3. Section 4 contains an interpretation of the statistical results in terms of the theoretical models in the light of additional historical and institutional information about Swedish trade and industrial policy. Other import restrictions and subsidies are briefly surveyed in Sections 5 and 6. 2. THEORETICAL BACKGROUND The existing structure of protection against imports in a country can be seen as a result of several factors, including: - the need for protection in different industries, i.e. the degree of import competition, which depends on the international competitiveness of the industry in question; - the incentives and the capacity by producers and/or labor associated with the industry to further their economic interests through the political system; - the goals of national economic policy, and the sensitivity of policy makers to claims for protection from different political groups. There has lately been a great deal of interest in empirical studies explaining the structure of protection in a country in terms of differences in industry characteristics, according to a theory of protection based on the theory of public choice. We will make no attempt to survey the literature here, nor to present the theories in detail (for a fuller treatment see Caves (1976), Anderson (1978, 1979) and Baldwin (1978)). The theory is based on the welfare maximization behavior of producers seeking protection, and of politicians offering protection to them in return for political support.
 Because of the high costs in relation to the benefits for consumers in obtaining information about tariffs and in resisting them, the tariff structure reflects mainly producers- interests. The greater the incentive for seeking protection, and thus the demand for it, from an industry, and/or the greater the propensity to grant protection to it, the greater the rate of protection for its product will be. The demand for protection will in turn depend on the economic gains that can be obtained (or the losses avoided) by protection. The main conclusions of the theory is that we would expect the rate of protection in an industry to be higher, the higher is: - the labor intensity measured as labor's share of value added (Anderson 1978), or the inverse of value added per worker (Caves 1976). This is because 'labor has the votes" and the political benefit of supplying protection to labor intensive industries will thus be great; - the degree of industry concentration, as measured by the share of sales of the (n) biggest firms (for alternative variables see Caves (1976) and Helleiner (1977)). Since the tariff is in a sense a "public good", its benefits are enjoyed by all firms in the industry, irrespective of their share in the cost of obtaining it. Hence, an industry consisting of a large number of small firms will face a serious "free rider" problem that will make it difficult to raise funds for lobbying for protection; - the hypothetical free trade import share of the market: the larger the import share, the greater are the potential gains from protection; and the lower is - the average wage (Anderson 1979) as well as the level of education and/or the proportion of skilled personnel in the labor force (Baldwin 1978). It can be argued that it is politically easier to motivate protection on grounds of "fairness" for such industries. In addition, low wage, unskilled workers have probably greater difficulty in finding new jobs; - the rate of growth of production and employment, since declining industries have a greater incentive to seek protection. These theories assume no specific goals for the government forming the industrial policy (other than remaining in office). In contrast, another approach, which we shall call the National Policy model (Caves 1976), is based on the idea that there exists a single "national" preference function, and that the existing structure of protection reflects an attempt to maximize it. The arguments of such a function, i.e. the goals of economic policy could be of a different kind. Certainly, it includes maximization of aggregate real income. As is well known, in a perfect economy this would imply free trade. Consequently, in explaining protection motivated by this goal only, one would look for different forms of market distortions. Since most market imperfections are probably caused by domestic distortions, and since it has
 _3- been shown that the best policy in such a case generally implies the use of subsidies and/or taxes rather than import restrictions, it might seem as though the widespread use of tariffs and quotas cannot be explained by the efficiency goal only. However, as Corden (1974) points out, if the raising of fiscal revenue is costly this may restrict the use of measures involving the public budget, in favor of tariffs. But other than income maximization goals are also relevant for industrial policy. An additional goal is income distribution. It has been argued (Corden 1974) that the social preference function is likely to be "conservative", i.e. preferences are strongly biased against any significant and rapid reduction of the incomes of any group. Import restrictions will then protect mostly "senescent industries", and industrial policy will be strongly adverse to rapid structural change. By taking account of uncertainty another argument can be introduced into the preference function beside the level and distribution of income, namely the variance in expected real income, i.e. in the amount of goods available for consumption. One source of uncertainty in the case of an open economy is the risk of the import supply being cut off, by acts of nature or political causes. If the policy makers dislike risk, the policy choice in a certain sector might be between inefficient but riskless domestic production (provided of course that the risk of domestic disturbances of supply is negligible) and imports obtainable at lower resource cost but with the possibility of being interrupted. Against the income maximization goal, that by itself would imply free trade, there stands the risk factor, implying a higher degree of self- sufficiency. The magnitude of the latter factor depends on the likelihood of an import cut-off, and on the consequences of such an event, which in turn has to do with the substitution possibilities in consumption (or use in production) of the product. These factors obviously vary between products, and they cannot be quantified in any simple way. Including uncertainty with respect to import supply results in a general tendency to use trade and industrial policy in such a way as to get a more diversified industrial structure than would be the case under free trade. We note that as the distortion lies in the fact that the private cost of imports is lower than its social cost (by an appropriate risk premium) the optimal policy in this case is a tariff, and not a subsidy. This variant of the National Policy model we shall call the Diversification model. The risk argument is certainly not the only one leading to a policy of industrial diversification. Nationalistic arguments are often used against dependence on imports and in favor of a "balanced", i.e. more diversified, industry (Caves 1976). We will argue that it is likely that the national preference function has properties implying that protection is used mainly to ascertain a satisfactory degree of diversification of the domestic economic structure. Taken to the extreme, this would mean that the structure of protection should be prohibitive, that is, it should compensate exactly for comparative disadvantage, i.e. for low international competitiveness due to high costs of production. This, of course, is the idea that lies behind "the scientific
 - 4 - tariff". The existing tariff structure could thus be explained by the potential free trade position of the home industry on the domestic market. Since this is not observable, the tariff structure can alternatively be explained by the factors determining comparative costs and international competitiveness. Let us suppose, in the spirit of the neoclassical theory of international trade, that the intensity of use in an activity of different factors of production is important in determining the relative cost. For a two-factor model with production functions of the Cobb-Douglas type, and with no intermediate goods, it can be shown (Travis 1972) that the unit cost in an industry, relative to the cost abroad, will depend only on the capital intensity and the relative level of efficiency of the industry in question (at given factor prices and exchange rate). If the domestic wage/capital price ratio is higher than abroad, the more labor intensive the process the higher its relative cost will be, and thus the worse its competitive position. On the home market, however, this cost disadvantage can be compensated for by an appropriate tariff. In fact, the tariff rate that is needed to stop imports will be a simple function of the capital intensity. If the immediate goal of industrial policy is diversification, then the rate of protection in different industries would be correlated with the intensity in use of the country's scarce (i.e. expensive) factor (see also Lundberg 1976). When we extend the result to a multi-factor world, it can be shown (see Appendix C) that comparative costs in any industry, and thus the necessary rate of protection, will be a linear function of the cost shares of different factors, provided that input coefficients are given and factor prices equal in all sectors. The results could also be extended to a model with tradeable intermediate goods. In that case, the rate of effective protection necessary to stop imports will be a simple function of the proportions in which factors are used directly in a production process. Should the intermediate goods be non-tradeable, on the other hand, the relation between factor intensities and protection will refer to the nominal rate of protection and the total--direct plus indirect--use of factors. At a given relative cost the domestic market share and thus the need for protection on the home market, will be influenced by transport cost. In general we expect the tariff to be lower, cet. par., for products for which transport costs are important in relation to costs of production, and which thus enjoy "natural" protection in the domestic market. The National Policy model may not only contain a general tendency to diversification and decreased international specialization, but also express a collective preference for a certain industrial structure. Certain activities may, in the opinion of policy makers, generate a social value in addition to the market value of their products (Johnson 1965). If some industries are protected for this reason, the question is what type of industries these are likely to be. We will argue here that such industries tend to be those with intensive use of advanced technology, on the grounds that such technology-producing activities are widely believed to give substantial positive external effects on technical progress in the rest of the economy. Whether this is true or not does not really matter: an equally important motive might be that such production adds to national prestige. We
 should then expect a high rate of protection for high-technology industries. This we will call the Technology hypothesis. 3. STATISTICAL RESULTS An analysis of the determinants of the structure of protection is met by many problems and questions, such as: 1. Some forms of protection, and/or their effects, are very difficult to quantify; this is especially true of some non-tariff barriers to trade. 2. Should all forms of protection be combined in a single measure, or should different forms be analyzed separately? 3. Should levels or changes in protection be studied? 4. Should existing protection be explained by variables reflecting current economic conditions? Do we deal with "equilibrium" structures of protection? 5. How can we account for interdependences among variables, for instance that the import share of the market affects the rate of protection, and at the same time is affected by it? In addition, we have to choose a suitable method of analysis. In our case data on a sufficiently disaggregated level to permit a meaningful use of econometric methods are available only for tariffs. We will thus treat each form of protection separately. We will study nominal as well as effective tariffs. The tariff data used in the study are the Swedish tariff rates before (1959) and after (1972) the Kennedy Round. Since the latter reflect multilateral tariff negotiation, the 1959 tariffs in our opinion are better suited to an analysis of the Swedish trade policy. INTERPRETATIONS OF THE RESULTS In order to be able to make any predictions whatsoever about the determinants of the Swedish tariff structure on the basis of the diversification hypothesis, we must at first establish which factors determine the comparative advantage of the Swedish economy. According to empirical studies, Swedish industry seems to have had a comparative advantage in physical capital intensive production, particularly in the 1950s, although the importance of this factor has probably declined, and later on in production using skilled labor intensively (Carlsson & Ohlsson 1976), Ohlsson (1973 and 1976). Studies of trade with developing countries indicate comparative advantage in products intensive in physcial plus human capital i.e. with high value added per employee (Carlsson & Sundstrom 1973). The predictions given by different theories of protection about the relationships between the level of protection and the explanatory variables are summarized in Table 4, together with the results of the econometric work. But because the theories are not rigorous, it is difficult 'to discriminate among them, since their predictions are very similar. In particular, it turns out that almost all variables supposed to affect the supply and demand for protection through various mechanisms, according to the theory of the political market for protection, can also be interpreted as indicators of comparative costs. We have tried to sum up the predictions of different theories in Table 4. This table is not a summary of the literature, but rather our own interpretation of the theories, concentrating on the main ideas. The positive sign for labor intensity (LD, LT) and the negative signs for skill intensity (Lu) and value added per employed (V) are predicted both by the adding machine/interest group theories and by the diversification hypothesis. The influence of the scale/concentration variables is predicted only by the interest group hypothesis. An effect of R&D intensity is predicted only by the technology hypothesis, but with the wrong sign. It is a striking result that the single common prediction of all theories, namely a positive sign for import penetration (I), fails to be significant, and that the relationship in the data concerns the net import (IN).

 - 15 - necessary, as Messerline (1980) points out, to study the behavior of "bureaucrats", as an additional type of actor. There are also other problems in using such models in an explanation of Swedish trade policy. It could be argued that the national policy model might be especially appropriate for an analysis of the structure of protection in small open economies, such as those of the Scandinavian countries. Firstly, there is a high degree of centralization of labor unions. There is also a comparatively high concentration of ownership of industry. In addition, regional governments and regional interest groups are less powerful in relation to the central government than in many other countries. For these reasons it may be difficult for workers and capital owners in a given industry to form powerful groups that can pursue their interests effectively, against the general consumer interest, inside the administration, the political parties and the trade unions. Agriculture is an obvious exception; here producers have succeeded in obtaining strong political support and massive protection. The development of trade policy in a small country is likely to be influenced by actual and potential policies of other countries to a very considerable extent. A small open economy is thus not only a price taker but also a "policy taker", in the sense that it has little power to influence the contents of multilateral agreements. The international influence is obvious in the historical development of Swedish trade policy from the beginning of industrialization, for it closely follows international trends and cycles of more liberal trade or greater protectionism. A small open economy is extremely vulnerable to retaliation. This is, no doubt, an important factor in explaining the relatively limited use of import restrictions in Swedish post-war industrial policy. In fact, fear of retaliation is a common argument against proposals for restrictions. The recent debate about subsidies to certain export industries makes clear that policy makers as well as firms are fully aware of such risks. Furthermore, almost all Swedish import restrictions in recent years have been directed towards those exporters which have the least power to retaliate, namely the developing countries. It could be argued that in a small economy the necessity of taking part in the international division of labor is obvious, and forms the core of attitudes towards trade policy. The strong posture in favor of international trade and specialization repeatedly taken by the LO, the central body of Swedish trade unions, is an example. The benefits of international trade and specialization have often been stressed by the industry organizations, where the interests of big and strongly export-oriented or transnational firms are prominent. Until recently there was virtually no influential group in any political party openly advocating generally protectionist views. There was, for instance, no articulate political opposition against the free trade agreements with EFTA and later with the EC. The debate centered around possible consequences for neutrality and freedom for national economic policy of a membership in an organization with supra-national powers, not around the question of free trade as such.

THE STRUCTURE AND DEVELOPMENT OF NON-TARIFF BARRIERS TO TRADE Due to lack of data, a meaningful econometric analysis cannot be undertaken of the determinants of other forms of protection than tariffs. However, qualitative judgement can examine the extent to which other barriers to trade fall into the same pattern as tariff protection. Quantitative import restrictions in Sweden on imports from market economies have been dominated by export restriction agreements on textiles and clothing from developing countries introduced in the mid-60s and successively extended to new products and countries. In addition there has also been a temporary global quota on footwear. According to Table 5, the industries protected by quantitative restrictions in the late 60s and 70s in Sweden: - had been the most stagnant with regard to employment in the 1960s; - had the largest increase in import penetration; - were among the most labor intensive; and - were also among those industries with the highest level of import penetration in the end of the 1960s. Furthermore, these industries are also characterized by low expenditure on R&D, they have a low level of average wage, do not use much skilled labor, and they were dominated by small firms and small plants. Except for the last point we could say that quantitative import restrictions show the same industry pattern as tariffs, namely, that they protect technically unsophisticated consumer products, intensive in use of labor, especially unskilled labor, which are stagnating or contracting as a consequence of strong and rapidly increasing import competition. The import quotas on textiles, clothing and footwear, together with other forms of protection granted to these industries in the 70s (such as subsidies to wages, to export promotion etc), were explicitly mainly motivated by the argument that import penetration in these industries would otherwise exceed a tolerable level which was determined by the need to keep some production capacity in case of a blockade of imports. This indicates that for some products, classified as "necessities" by some definition, there would exist some critical upper limit of import penetration, that would trigger off protective measures. This critical level is not, of course, necessarily the same for all products.

SUBSIDIES One of the principles of the Swedish industrial policy during the post-war years has been to promote growth in such technology intensive sectors as nuclear power, computers and aircraft production. One form of assistance to these industries has been preferential treatment in public procurement, as an attempt to create a protected home market. However, most of these efforts have failed. Some of these failures have been very costly. The failure to secure an export market has been an important cause of failure because the home market is too small to sustain production at reasonable cost. The main reason for giving assistance to the establishment of such industries seems to have been the belief of policy makers in the importance of building up domestic technical knowledge in these fields. Thus, the industry as well as local politicians and trade unions have been active. In the political decision about the development of a new military aircraft during the 1980s this decision will determine whether the domestic aircraft producer will survive. Up to middle of the 1970s the government subsidies, outside agriculture, the defence industry and certain other sectors, were probably not of any great significance. During the 70s, however, there has been a marked increase in the use of subsidies of various kinds. Firstly, does the increased use of sectoral subsidies reflect a change in policy goals, away from free trade? Secondly, what explains the choice of policy measures? And thirdly, what are the characteristics of the industries that have obtained assistance? Before answering those questions, we must consider if the figures in Table 6 really signify an increase in the level of permanent protection, with the same long run intended consequences on industrial structure as tariffs and quotas, or if they are merely temporary measures, used to control the speed and consequences of an adjustment process towards a more efficient structure. On this point it is not possible to give a definite answer. The motives given, of course, are of a short run character: however, some, though not all, of the assistance will presumably be permanent. It is possible that political opinion in Sweden has become somewhat sceptical of the benefits of free trade, and more sympathetic towards protection arguments; many of the latter are being directed against "unfair" competition from export zones in developing countries. However, we believe that the common preference for free trade has remained basically unchanged within all major political and economic groups. The increased use of subsidies is mainly to be seen as a substitute for an efficient stabilization policy. The failure of fiscal, exchange rate and incomes policy to counteract foreign and domestic disturbances has left the policy burden to selective measures. This is, of course, a very general phenomenon that can be observed in most countries from the '30s onward. At the same time, the potential changes in employment were too large to be dealt with by adjustment assistance alone. Most industry support in Sweden in the '70s has been given in the form of domestic subsidies, rather than restrictions on imports. This marks a general trend in industrial policy away from restrictions on trade and in
 - 21 - particular tariffs, toward domestic subsidies. Secondly, the measures have been increasingly selective, i.e. not only discriminating between industries and regions but also selective with respect to firms. These "marginal" subsidies are likely to have the same effects on resource allocation, but they are favored for income distribution reasons; i.e. they are less costly for the public budget. There are many reasons for the trend toward more selective domestic subsidies. Firstly, in the -70s some of the problem industries were hurt by competition in export markets, and would have benefited very little from protection of the domestic market. An obvious example is forestry, but this is also true for shipyards. Secondly, the use of import restrictions has become increasingly circumscribed by global and regional agreements, such as the GATT, the EC, etc. The fear of retaliation probably also explains why the use of global import restrictions has been limited. Thirdly, the goals of economic policy have become more ambitious. In particular, the increased stress on the regional dimension, for instance on local labor market conditions, has made increasing selectivity necessary. The need for more differentiated policy measures, finally, has been accentuated by slow economic growth and less favorable attitudes toward structural change. Insofar as protection for some products could be motivated by the existence of domestic distortions--for instance the private costs of the use of some factors of production overestimated the social costs--the change from import restrictions to domestic subsidies could be seen as an improvement with respect to economic efficiency. However, this is not likely to have been the main reason. In some cases, the differential effects on income distribution may have weighed in favor of subsidies. The industries assisted by domestic subsidies seem to have been less homogenous with respect to characteristics of the production process, the market and industrial structure, than the industries protected by import restrictions. Some industries, of course, belong to both groups. There are the "old" problem industries, like the footwear, the textiles and clothing industries, and the manual glass industry. Of these, footwear and clothing are labor intensive while all use standardized techniques and are not intensive in skilled labor (except glass) or in R&D. But domestic assistance has also been enjoyed by some very capital intensive industries, such as steel mills. However, the most assisted industry, shipyards, is rather labor intensive, though mostly in skilled labor, and has had a rapid increase in import penetration during the '70s. In addition, both steel and shipyards are concentrated in vary large plants. The industries in Table 7 face different problems, and have different forms of protection, but such a discussion would bring us outside the limits of this paper: for a case study of the shipyards see Hamilton (1980). A common characteristic is, however, that selective assistance has been granted in an acute crisis to some or all firms in an industry, with the main objective of avoiding (or postponing) very large relative decreases of employment in a local or regional labor market. There is a difference between "new" and "old" problem industries: in textiles and footwear, for instance, the motives for assistance seem to be more "genuinely protectionist" (a minimum level of self-sufficiency), as do the means (tariffs and quotas) than in the "new" industries.

CONCLUSIONS Our statistical results indicate that Swedish effective tariffs seem to protect industries that are labor intensive, in particular in the use of unskilled labor, produce standardized products using simple technology, as measured by a low share of R&D in sales, have a weak overall international competitive position, i.e. a high net import share, and are concentrated in large plants. In addition, nominal tariffs are high on final products with a low raw material content. However, the statistical significance is in some cases rather low. Quantitative restrictions on imports have been imposed in declining sectors with a high level and/or a high rate of increase of import penetration. Preferences in public procurement seem to be most important in sectors with advanced technology. Domestic subsidies have been given both to capital intensive and to labor intensive industries. Subsidized industries have generally been characterized by declining profitability, a weakening market position, and the size concentration of plants. Our statistical results are broadly consistent both with the adding machine and the interest group theories of protection. They are also consistent with the diversification hypothesis, i.e. that the general goal of protection is a more diversified economic structure, and that tariffs are calculated to compensate for high comparative costs. It is, of course, not an easy task to forecast Swedish industrial policy in the 1980s. However, by extrapolating from current policy goals and methods one could argue that the following pattern seems probable. Some form of assistance is likely to be granted to industries mainly in three kinds of circumstances. The first is when the industry uses advanced technology. Much of theassistance in the case of technologically leading sectors will be given in disguised forms, such as preferences in public procurement and subsidies to R&D. The second kind will be products which can be considered as necessities" by some definition, where an increasing import penetration reaches a very high, critical level. In this case most types of protective measures, including import restrictions, will probably be used. The third case is the industry with big plants, dominating a local labor market, in acute crisis, due to global overproduction or national loss of competitiveness. In this case assistance will be given by subsidies, some of which will have a permanently protective effect. The appearance of new "problem industries" will be more likely if the current macroeconomic situation prevails. The use of trade restrictions in Sweden will probably closely follow international developments. This means that most assistance in the three cases discussed will take the form of subsidies. However, it is possible that the increasingly difficult budget situation will lead to a more frequent use of import restrictions, as a substitute for financially "costly" forms of assistance.

doc.abstracts: The project seeks to establish the shares of industrial country markets held by the developing countries, changes in such shares in the 1970s, and why they vary among industry groups and countries. The aim is to assist developing and industrial countries to improve their policies through a better understanding of trade patterns and protectionist pressures. This paper studies the determinants of the inter-industry pattern of tariffs, non-tariff barriers to trade and domestic subsidies in Sweden, in the light of different hypotheses about causes of protection. The statistical results show that Swedish nominal and effective tariffs protect labor intensive industries in which protection is concentrated in large plants, that are not intensive in the use of skilled labor and research and development. The results are consistent with the hypothesis that the general goal of trade policy is to diversify the industrial structure by compensating for high comparative costs. Quantitative restrictions on imports follow much the same pattern, but subsidized industries are less homogenous.
